body: also, why do queries from broker node have been working both before and after this change if the timestamp was never present?

isnt this implied by the 'type'?
a 'string' is a dimension, a 'float' is a metric.

updating this bug after talking with Eric Tschetter.
The timestamp was still being included in both schemas. Just that in the first schema the timestamp node was also being added as a dimension. this explains why broker could query perfectly. still doesnt explain #732 or the exception.

the reindex task looks fine,I wonder if the segments you reindexed had metrics values set to 0 for some rows, what happens when u run the same select query after ingesting your data without rerolling it up using ingestSegmentfirehose, do you still see zero values for some rows ?

the values are not 0 before the indexing.
in fact i spent an hour with Eric Tschetter and he verified that this is indeed an issue with druid itself.

will update after ingesting without rolling.

Because of the segments are replicants of each other, only 1 copy is uploaded. This is expected behavior.

Hi @gbuisson, you should use the `/discovery/[...]` path to discover druid nodes.
We use the standard [service discovery extension](http://curator.apache.org/curator-x-discovery/index.html) provided by curator, which can also used for other services. Since it is not druid specific, we put it at the root level.

That being said, you are correct the default Druid configuration is `/druid/discovery/`.
The discovery path is configurable using the `druid.discovery.curator.path` setting, so I will probably change the docker build to use the default to reduce confusion and make it less confusing.

In any case, the discovery path should be configurable on the client side as well to account for the configuration parameter.

Alright, thank you.

/discovery is fine and eases integration with other services.

However, if you're going to have a look at the docker repo, there's another
thing i wish to report.

Nodes on /discovery are advertised with "localhost" as their hostname, I
guess it's default docker config, but I thought maybe it could be changed
to ease connection tests thought zk, what's your opinion ?

Thanks for the contrib! Before I can merge the pull request, we need you to
agree to our CLA. In the repo there is an individual CLA and a corporate
CLA. If you are working on your own behalf and agree to the CLA, responding
here with a comment of "I agree to the terms of the Druid Individual CLA as
it exists in the current master branch" is sufficient. If you are working on
behalf of a company, can you have your company fill out the corporate CLA
and submit it to us? Thanks again!

hi @zhenchuan, 20k-30k records per sec definitely seems very slow. As @nishantmonu51 mentioned, more information will help.
@zhenchuan Yes, if Druid cannot connect to ZK or cannot successfully hand-off, it will keep the segment and try to handoff again next segment granularity.
BTW @zhenchuan, we are slower responding here than https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/druid-development
Hi @ethanocentricity, the limit does save computation and prevents a large search result from eating up the heap. TopN queries also limit results.
@pdeva, what TaskLogs implementation are you using? (Your druid.indexer.logs.type property.) Also are you seeing this issue while a task is still running, or only after it finishes? Or both?

Nm, took a look at the code and it looks like "file" and "hdfs" don't respect negative offsets. So I assume you were using one of those. The others look okay.

Can we also add some documentation on how to choose a particular metadata storage implementation, and what the required configuration parameters are?
Currently, if the mysql-metadata-storage module is not added as an extension, Druid defaults to derby, even if we select mysql. Druid should error out instead if it can't find the required module.
Benchmarks show ~10% improvement on large queries (threshold of 100 or more), approx same to worse performance when the threshold is very small (10)
As per the code, we've established that it is an array of strings, not objects, but the doc should be updated to show that any number of dataSources can be specified, not just two.
Does arbitrary order make sense, if you want your commonly queried dimensions to be sorted next to each other, indexed and merged together ?

Supposedly: on Oracle JVM this is only activated when setting `-XX:+UseThreadPriorities` and running the JVM as root, or setting `-XX:+UseThreadPriorities -XX:ThreadPriorityPolicy=42` (where 42 is any number neither 0 nor 1). See [this thread](http://www.akshaal.info/2008/04/javas-thread-priorities-in-linux.html)

Has it changed at all since java 6?

Cheers,
Steve

> On Nov 3, 2014, at 9:02 PM, Dr. Charles Allen notifications@github.com wrote:
> 
> Supposedly: on Oracle JVM this is only activated when setting -XX:+UseThreadPriorities and running the JVM as root, or setting -XX:+UseThreadPriorities -XX:ThreadPriorityPolicy=42 (where 42 is any number neither 0 nor 1). See this thread
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.

High level comment:

There's a forking task runner that the middle manager uses that sets JVM args for the peons. I think we can add "-XX:+UseThreadPriorities" there to force thread priorities in child JVMs.

Unknown, good question.

METAMARKETS http://www.metamarkets.com/m 765.490.0454|t @drcrallen
https://twitter.com/drcrallencharles.allen@metamarkets.com

I'm sort of confused about the goal of this PR. IIRC the thread pool task runner doesn't typically get more than one task, since it only exists inside one peon, which just runs one task and then exits.

@gianm Simply put: RealTime indexing nodes service queries at the same time as archiving. This small window causes nasty query response times during the archive/persisting period. I'm hoping honoring thread priority will allow the OS to properly give priority to any interactive responses instead of causing interactive responses to compete for compute resources with the archiving task.

Ah, so this is actually an OS thread priority that could work across processes, and not just within the same process? That makes sense then.

It may also be interesting to change the task priority from explicitly being a thread priority to being something more vague. This could let us use it for other things, like cluster scheduling- possibly running tasks out of order if there is not enough capacity to run the entire backlog.

@gianm I'm very open to doing that. currently it is just handled as an int and would be up to the resource pool implementation to determine what that int means. Following the Threads priority specification gives at least some logic to it.

It does give some logic to it but I'm concerned about it being potentially confusing logic. I think someone trying to understand the priority behaviors later would see the Thread constants and assume priority is about thread priority, and then be surprised later to find out it's also used for unrelated things like cluster scheduling. So I'm in favor of inventing an explicit task priority space and mapping that space onto other kinds of priorities as appropriate.

If that's not convincing and you still want to keep task priority space identical to Thread priority space, that's okay, just please write a comment explaining the situation.

@drcrallen 

The error "I failed to find the right cookie" can be explained by the fact that during the serialization of a roaring bitmap, a 32-bit "cookie" is written out as part of the header. When we attempt to deserialize the bitmap, we first check for the presence of this cookie. If it is not found, then we bail out with an error.
